title: 115_hr2916
content: The Act may be cited as the "Charities Helping Americans Regularly Throughout the Year Act of 2017". The Senate expresses a sense relating to the protection of charitable deductions. The Senate finds that the deduction for charitable contributions has been important for almost 100 years, encouraging taxpayers to give for the benefit of others. Nonprofit organizations provided 11.4 million jobs in 2012, and in 2015, charitable giving totaled $373.25 billion, accounting for 2.1% of the GDP. The Senate believes that tax reform should aim to promote charitable giving. The Senate believes that tax reform should promote charitable giving and ensure that the deduction for charitable contributions is not reduced during tax code reform. SEC. 3 amends the standard mileage rate for charitable contributions deduction, ensuring it is not less than the rate used for medical expenses. The amendment applies to miles traveled after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 4 modifies substantiation requirements for charitable contributions. SEC. 4 amends the substantiation requirements for charitable contributions by renumbering subparagraphs. SEC. 5 mandates electronic filing for annual returns of exempt organizations starting after December 31, 2016. The amendment requires organizations to electronically file their annual returns, which will be made available to the public in machine-readable format. The effective date for these changes is for taxable years beginning after the enactment of the Act, with transitional relief for small organizations. The amendment mandates electronic filing of annual returns for organizations, with public access in machine-readable format. Transitional relief is provided for small organizations, allowing a delay of up to 2 years after the Act's enactment. The amendment allows small organizations with gross receipts under $200,000 and assets under $500,000 to delay filing Form 990-T or required returns under section 6033 of the Internal Revenue Code. The Secretary may delay amendments made by this section until 2 years after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 6. MODIFICATION OF RULES RELATING TO DONOR ADVISED FUNDS. SEC. 6. MODIFICATION OF RULES RELATING TO DONOR ADVISED FUNDS. Allowance of Tax-Free Charitable Distributions From Individual Retirement Accounts amended for distributions after December 31, 2016. Return disclosures for distributions under subsection (k) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 are also modified. The text chunk discusses the reporting requirements for organizations with donor-advised funds, including listing the total number of funds, the number of funds that made grants, and the organization's policy on inactive funds. The amendment made by this subsection requires organizations with donor-advised funds to regularly monitor and enforce compliance with their policies. Effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2017. SEC. 7 amends the tax rate for investment income of private foundations from 2 percent to 1 percent and eliminates reduced tax for foundations meeting certain distribution requirements. These changes apply to taxable years starting after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 8 provides an exception from excess business holdings tax for certain philanthropic business holdings. The amendment to Section 4943 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 provides an exception for certain philanthropic business holdings of private foundations, meeting specific ownership, profit distribution, and operational requirements. The amendment to Section 4943 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows private foundations to hold ownership interests in business enterprises acquired through a will or trust. The business enterprise must distribute its net operating income to the private foundation within 120 days after the close of the taxable year to meet the all profits to charity requirement. The net operating income of a business enterprise for a taxable year is its gross income reduced by deductions, taxes, and a reasonable reserve for working capital. Independent operation requirements are met if maintained throughout the year. Requirements for a private foundation include ensuring that no substantial contributor or their family member is involved in the business enterprise, and the majority of the foundation's board of directors are not affiliated with the enterprise. The subsection excludes certain deemed private foundations, trusts described in section 4947(a)(1), and any fund or organization treated as a private foundation by reason of subsection (e) or (f). The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2017.
